Limestone Ziggurat.title: 107A-2
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
In February of 1959, in Cape Canaveral, the United States Air Force successfully tested the first multistage intercontinental ballistic missile, or ICBM - given the designation of Titan I. Although these missiles were only in use between 1959 and 1962, their subsequent iterations would continue to be developed for warfare and security purposes, acting as a nuclear deterrent until 1987.
The 107A-2 weapon system encompassed all equipment and bases related to these ICBMs, with the Titan missiles being the first designed to be housed within underground silos - the interior wall of one such silo reproduced here as an album cover.
LSZ recordings continue to serve as a source of both historical information about, and a protest against, the United States nuclear program, as well as a wider condemnation of war and governance through fear, violence and destruction. As it has been stated on prior LSZ releases before: We are no closer to peace or safety, sleeping with these instruments of suffering beneath our pillow.
PATCH NOTES (2023/02/06):
Ornament & Crime (Hemispheres / Vector LFO) utilized two stepped-waveform LFOs in the audible range (tuned to 87.06hz and 88.02hz, respectively), which were externally fed additional modulation via a Behringer 1005 Modamp's inharmonic preset CV outs, while the 1005 also ring modulated both audio signals. The resultant audio was routed through a Beep Boop Kontact gain circuit, then multed into Mutable Inst Clouds and Noise Engineering's Versio (running the Multi Versio alt firmware in the Lo-Fi mode). The Versio's output was hard panned L/R in the mixer, while Clouds' output consisted of altered higher pitch shifting, and further stereo filtering via two low-pass filters (2HP and Doepfer A-121-3). Both filters were modulated with parallel/inverse sine LFOs from a Behringer 150 (itself modulated by a Behringer 1004 and a Buchla 258t to create dynamic modulation sweeps), which panned them continually, and this signal was sent through a Disting Mk4 in Stereo Delay (M6) mode, where finally the dry and delay signals were mixed and sent into hard-panned L/R in the mixer. All four output signals were summed and sent into a Zoom H1 digital recorder, which relayed the audio to Goldwave for capturing on the computer. Final mastering and post-session parametric equalization were done via FL Studio 20.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: A Song for the Roaming Damned
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Sun drips down on the seedless night
Not warmed by this slack caress
Immured, like a hole filled with rain
Underneath the singed clouds, an echo of a dull sound
Reverberating from across the battered landscape
Tongueless and spare, gasping
Long ago emptied of hope
A husk shaped like a man, dragging a post through the blasted gravel
Saturated with the weight of a burnt memory
N.B. Timbral Ocean II

Limestone Ziggurat.title: A Wreath for Pandrosion
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
A loop study with the Moog Subharmonicon and the BeepBoop Tape Sampler, mixed and mastered with careful restraint in mono, using digital signal processors from Airwindows (Distance / Purest Gain) and Arturia (Mini Filter / EMT Plate). "A Wreath for Pandrosion" is offered as a free download for Women's Day, reflecting on a woman that historians believe was one of the first women to substantially develop mathematics, even before Hypatia.
It is surreal to be writing these words in 2025, and to feel that there are people reading them who would see both women and mathematics as radical things. As the father of a daughter and the husband of a wife who both deeply love mathematics, as well as a musician who often thinks about the profound contributions women have made to all the richest things in my life - music, literature, art, computing - I can sincerely state that every day is Women's Day in my home, just as every day should be Earth Day. Certainly, we'd cease to exist without either.
mathshistory.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Pandrosion/

Limestone Ziggurat.title: A220
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Originally released on the 1st of June in 2021 at Celebrate Psi Phenomenon, as a part of the second "PSI-SOLATION" compilation. I've written a lot about my adoration for both Campbell Kneale's music as Birchville Cat Motel/Our Love Will Destroy The World as well as his storied C/Psi/P imprint - without both Kneale's work as a musician and his operation of that label, none of my work under any moniker would be what it is today, and Milieu Music as a label might not exist either. So it follows that when Limestone Ziggurat was ready for the world as a new project of mine, it meant so much to me to be able to debut it at Kneale's label, and I cannot thank him enough for indulging me an album-length work submitted to his compilation to make this happen.
So why this piece, to start with? It wasn't really a completely unique or remarkable piece to debut an entire project with, but this was sort of the point at the time. I'd conceived of a project that would use primarily the modular system to make things as early as 2020, my thinking also coinciding with the pandemic, and at that time I wanted to let it gestate through various informal and primordial sessions (some have since been released as 'Adamantinarx' and the forthcoming 'Isotelus') in order to determine what the project would *actually* consist of, after the novelty of whatever self-imposed "newness" wore off and work continued in a more settled fashion.
"A220" was one of a crop of sessions from early 2021, which were strong indicators that Limestone Ziggurat had arrived. It was recorded live, and a broadcast of this session was attempted, but errors kept it from being usable and whatever visual record was made at the time has since been lost. The name and the sound both refer back to the sonic seed at the center of the recording - an A220 pitch in a test oscillator tone present in Behringer's 305 mixer, designed as a reference for tuning other oscillators against, which somewhat infamously does not remain in tune if it is left to oscillate.
This simple sinewave was both multed and re-processed through things like Clouds as well as augmented by other oscillators in the early modular system, such as the 3340 "Curtis chip" VCO and Cre8audio's Chips dual-oscillator, and more sinewaves via self-oscillating low-pass filters and phasers. There were multiple LFOs from Behringer and Dreadbox driven into the audible range, and Mutable Instruments' Rings was employed for thick resonant slabs that waft over the foundation of held-tones. I cannot remember exactly, but I may have also been using the "Blue Marvin" ARP 2600 remake from Behringer in this session too. I did not start keeping detailed patch notes until later on, and somehow, that missing information makes "A220" more interesting to me now.
Knowing I wanted to give "A220" a proper singular re-release now that LSZ has blossomed into what it is, I sat down last September to record a completely new take of "A220" using the system as it now exists. This session has been offered here in support of the first, labeled as "Phase II," and the very simple patch notes have been included in the track information. It consists of the same A220 test tone oscillator alongside three other Behringer sinewaves from the 1004, 921 and 140 modules - the latter being an LFO driven into the audible range.
This reissue also comes with a brilliant photograph taken by a friend on the other side of the globe who generously offered me her talents back when the project I wanted to use the image with didn't even have a name. It echoed a photo I took of my own backyard, and both are included on the physical edition of this set.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:

Cover photograph by Pragmaticunt, used with gracious permission. Back cover photograph by Brian at White Pillar, 2021. This is Milieu Music number Δ±220, first in the Voltaic Delta subcatalog of Limestone Ziggurat and LSZ reissued works. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Academic Vert Thrash
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Testing session with the DSM02 Character module by Dave Smith Instruments, a now-discontinued stereo signal processor that consists of five different digital effects that share the same signal path - a low and high exciter, a bit reducer, a sample rate reducer and a gain. For the most part, the DSM02 has been plucked directly from the Prophet 12 and Pro 2 synthesizers that Dave Smith produced, and isolated here for the modular format.
In this session, you hear squarewave oscillators from the Buchla 258t and the VCZIII A from Feedback Modules, frequency modulating one another, before being sent through the hard-panned stereo inputs on the DSM02. The DSM02's modulation inputs for Girth, Air, Decimate and Hack are all receiving envelopes from the Buchla 281t Quad Function Generator, which itself is receiving eight different sources of constantly shifting modulation from the Buchla 266t Source of Uncertainty and the 257t Voltage Processor, which separately control the attack and decay stages of the 281t's four envelopes. The stereo output of the DSM02 was routed through the Strymon Magneto four-head tape delay system, following a modulated amplifier path for both oscillators in a Doepfer A-135-2, which also received modulation from the Source of Uncertainty. The final output from Magneto was sent into two inputs on the Toppobrillo Minimix, and was recorded in GoldWave where the track was overlaid on itself, truncated and pitch shifted.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Accension Oil
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
The fruits of a long and exhaustive day (and my first) studying NonlinearCircuits' Fourier.
Clock source is A-188 (512) and A-188 (1024) routed into Boolean (CMOS Party), with NOR output sent into Doepfer A-160 clock divider, which sends the /4 output to clock input 1 on Fourier.
Fourier's two output paths are first sent to 2HP and Doepfer low-pass filters, then to Buchla 292 low pass gates (swept open and closed by Buchla Quad Function Generator 281), then to Strymon Magneto, to Starlab and finally to inputs 1 and 6 of the Toppobrillo Minimix, which are modulated in the panning from L/R by the Quad Function Generator 281 and Voltage Processor 257.
Following this, three different pitch iterations of the session were overlaid and panned in FL20, with some additional parametric equalization, delay and pitch shifting done in FL20 and Goldwave.
Of a pair with yesterday's album from the same session, "Binding the Appointed" - where one is the fire, the other is the ash.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Achaemenid Cube
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Achaemenid Cube" is a work that exists in superposition - that is, it consists of two separate albums, one issued as LSZ and one issued as Limestone Ziggurat, neither of which are considered the original work. They are two sides of the same six-sided object, and yet they are unique and apart from one another.
Perhaps, visually, you could consider one the outer surfaces of the cube, and the other the inner surfaces of that same cube. Or you could simply look at it pragmatically, knowing fully my predisposition for overly (and unnecessarily) complex concepts applied to what is essentially just another double album. With that notion in mind, I would counter with the questions: If you have always done things one way, and find a way to do them another way, why would you continue to do things as you always have? Why would you decide to make a change?
My thinking, when working on pieces like "Achaemenid Cube," is relative to the creative process itself, and the machines I have used to explore these ideas in the first place. Both albums originated using the same patch in the same modular system, with the only differences between them being the waveform shape of the oscillators themselves, and yet this is itself such a fundamental alteration that the entirety of the output changes - the same machines, the same connections between them, and only the manner of speech in their electrical communication changed from sinusoidal to consonant. This iteration of "Achaemenid Cube" contains the six Planar Regions in Sine, while the Ziggurat iteration contains the six Planar Regions in Pulse.
Offered as a visual accompaniment are photographs of two iterations of the same structure, built in two different areas by the Zoroastrian Persians in the distant past. Only educated guesses remain today to tell us what these cuboid structures were intended for - tombs, landmarks, temples of worship? Building a sacred fire? Housing sacred texts? As many reading and listening already know, I often find the remnants of the ancient world enthralling, and it is a continuous source of strangely useful information to spur on the creative act, when I often sit down to work on a modular patch and need only raw inputs of numerators to begin.
The past still exists, as evidenced by these ruins, and it is a remarkable feeling to know that something still standing today can be so old that even the ancient world did not know what it meant. Perhaps that alone is reason enough to build and create, if only to make the children of the future wonder.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released March 3, 2025
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, 30th-31st December 2024 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system, with secondary session work completed on 19th January 2025. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D using visual sampling of a photograph by Faramarz. This is Milieu Music number ON-25/062a. Sound recording (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Aius Loquens
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Both action and inaction may find room in thee."
-Helena Patrovna Blavatsky, excerpt from "The Voice of Silence" (1889)
---
Initally recorded alongside some Deep Urth session work on 25th September 2024, "Aius Loquens" is a nearly-naked exploration of the Cre8audio Chips noise oscillator, which is somewhere between a pulse wave, a sample & hold and low frequency noise.
In order to "hear" this oscillator in more musical terms, it has been used to engage the paraphonic Karplus-Strong synthesizer voices in Mutable Instruments' Rings, which (despite being a somewhat stereotypical staple in the wide world of modular music) continues to illustrate all kinds of interesting shapes and sounds as my modular system expands around it.
Both Chips and Rings were two of the earliest modules incorporated into my modular system, so it is interesting to hear them isolated in this way, despite the strangeness and sometimes raw recording quality of the session. "Aius Loquens" is another example (like the recent "O-E U" or earlier releases like "Sill" and "A Moon With No Sky") in the LSZ canon that explores melodic music that more or less forsakes melodic resolutions or chordal conventions, and instead presents melodicism as something not entirely different than rhythmic programming, and this becomes especially apparent when the overtone generation present in Karplus-Strong voices offers sound-forms that are not quite percussion, and not quite fretboard music either.
Experimentally, the session also dabbles in different avenues of both voltage and audio processing, sometimes using a modulated low-pass filter to unconventionally attenuate the noise oscillator, pushing occasional swells of resonation that bristle through the Karplus triggering mechanisms like a blown pipe. In other cases, Goldwave was utilized for granular resampling, fast Fourier transforms and stereo difference in order to isolate and accentuate certain aspects of the stereo image while ignoring most of the mono material.
Altogether, "Aius Loquens" is emblematic of many different but equally active paths of development under the LSZ banner, and exercises a beautiful position of asceticism in its singular focus on only one voice and one unorthodox sequencing source for that voice. It may not be for everyone, but nothing of interest ever is.

released November 12, 2024

(C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Algul Siento
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
More absolute music, this time a held-tone wall using predominantly Waldorf software synthesizers. A dense patch in Largo (Waldorf's earliest VST adjacent to their Blofeld synthesizer - don't tell Ian Fleming), using all twelve available voices (eight of which being wavetables) with each voice frequency modulating itself to some degree. From there, the entire output was multed twice - once through Waldorf's D-Pole for tuned ring modulation and delay, and again through another two instances of D-Pole, for inverted stereo delay and a faux BBD chorus. Aside from these, the only other processors used were two instances of Arturia's Minifilter for some low pass filtering and additional gain. The cover image was itself designed using only a screencap of Largo while the patch was being recorded.
Here's to four more years in the abyss.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Alight With Bels
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
“To know that you do not know is the best.
To pretend to know when you do not know is a disease.”
—Lao Tzu
'Alight With Bels' is a branching path from 'H. Temple' - issued on a split with NYZ (David Burraston, Noyzelab, et al -  pspsph.bandcamp.com/album/sem-ngexpz2-h-temple  ) to raise money for the NAACP Legal Defense Fund on Juneteenth. It has been plucked from the archive of "possible pasts" to be planted here in the Urth, a milemarker for the Autumnal Equinox.
The year has passed by so quickly that I feel it was only a short while ago I was writing the same sentiments. Time remains relative, even when I bury myself so deeply in the sound that I hear, hopelessly chasing some sweetly impossible ambivalence. Already, no sooner than the moment these syllables have left my mouth, are they transformed into the laughter of the past - the last black joke from the white visage of Yorick.
Cat#: ON-24/267

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Allow Nothing to Remain as It Was
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
N.B. Graciously offered here for its first physical edition, "Allow Nothing" was originally published digitally at Riff Merchant Records in 2024. Special thanks are owed to the Riff Merchant himself for personally approving this second iteration of the work.  riffmerchant.bandcamp.com/album/allow-nothing-to-remain-as-it-was
All purchases of the "Allow Nothing" 2xCD-R set include a digital download code for "The Grave of the Ocean King"
---
So we stepped out again
As the sky filled in
With the spilled ink of the abyss
Totality darkness
I could feel it like a fabric
Saturating the air
And I couldn't see you there beside me
Nearness diffused
In a silent cloak
And I wondered if you could still see me
My hands too washed in the black
Erasing everything
Reversing the daylight
Overwhelmed in this bereft space
Time slowed in a pause
Gratefully, I began to feel it return
Nothing yet visible
In this liminal gradient
Hearing then, your voice
Touching your hand to mine
Only now realizing the gulf we crossed
No longer disconnected
We smiled at the treeline
Off to the side of our house
Leaning its own shadows across the wall
Lucid and harmless
A silhouette shaped only by the sun

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Alsciaukat
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about: Three test sessions for a build of Mutable Instruments' Links utility module from the ever-reliable Happy Unicorn in Poland. These sessions predominantly rely on sound sources from the six modules in my Buchla 200 system - the 292t Quad Lo Pass Gate, the 281t Quad Function Generator, the 257t Voltage Processor, the 266t Source of Uncertainty, the 258t Dual Oscillator and the 245t Sequential Voltage Source - and experiment with the three distinct components of Links, which are a 1:3 multiple, a 2:2 unity mixer and a 3:1 summing mixer. Additional modulation and processing was sourced from Strymon's Magneto four-head tape delay system, Beepboop's Tape Sampler in the filter mode and Toppobrillo's Minimix, particularly channel inputs 1 and 6 which feature dedicated modulation controls for their stereo panning. Post-proc includes some equalization via Pulsar W495, low-pass filtering via Goldwave and compression via Audio Damage Rough Rider 3.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released December 19, 2024
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, 22nd October 2024 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system. Mastered 18th December 2024 by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D using visual sampling of a light curve for BN Lyncis, plotted from Hipparcos data by PopePompous. This is Milieu Music number ONE-24/296. Sound recording (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

trackinfo.lyrics: Buchla 258t oscillator 1 (sine to saw) sent into Links 2:2 input, with one output signal being sent into Beepboop Tape Sampler in filter mode, and the other sent into Links' 1:3 mult section. The three multed signals were routed back into the Buchla oscillator - one into the processing input, one into the frequency modulation input and one into the waveshape control input. From the Tape Sampler, the signal was routed into Strymon's Magneto in shift mode, then from Magneto into low pass filters from 2HP and Doepfer, which were finally mixed in Toppobrillo Minimix, with the 281t Quad Function Generator modulating the panning.

trackinfo.lyrics: Buchla 281t Quad Func Gen sent two oscillators in the audible range to both inputs in the 2:2 midsection of Mutable Inst. Links. The resultant two mixed outputs were then routed into Buchla 292t Quad Lo Pass Gate for slightly different level attenuation, then into Strymon Magneto. Two other oscillators in the 281t were used to modulate the L/R panning on inputs 1 and 6 of the Toppobrillo Minimix with those channels' dedicated CV inputs, and these were also pushed nearly into the audible range.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Amchixtax̂
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Amchixtax̂ is the Aleut name for what is now known as Amchitka, a small volcanic island in southwest Alaska, and one of the least stable tectonic environments in the United States. It was populated for over 2500 years by the Aleut people, and in 1971, became the site of the largest underground nuclear test (five megaton) in United States history, Cannikin. On today's date in 1971, the first Greenpeace vessel set out to the island in a voyage of protest, which ultimately failed. Prior to this, Amchitka was also used to host a White Alice communications system from 1959 to 1961. The Department of Energy continues to monitor the site as part of their remediation program. This is expected to continue until 2025, after which the site is intended to become a restricted access wildlife preserve.
This recording's album cover is a photograph of an artificial lake that was created to fill in the borehole at Cannikin, taken by L. Sheader and reproduced here with gratitude.
PATCH NOTES:
Mutable Inst. Braids, running Renaissance alt. firmware, using the wavetable chord algorithm of six oscillators, routed into a Future Sound Systems MTX9A pin matrix, multed as follows:
Iteration 1: MTX9A > Doepfer A-121-3 > LPF > MTX9A summed out
Iteration 2: MTX9A > Mutable Inst. Rings input > Odd output > MTX9A summed out
Iteration 3: MTX9A > SSDP Phasr > Wildfire Labs Equation Group > MTX9A summed out
Iteration 4: MTX9A > SSDP Phasr allpass filter out > Wildfire Labs Lucy Says No feedback loop (routed to input 8 on Equation Group) > 2HP LPF > MTX9A summed out
Iteration 5: MTX9A > Doepfer A-121-3 > BPF > 2HP Pitch Shifter > MTX9A summed out
(Iterations 1-5 summed by MTX9A > split to two outputs > Strymon Magneto L/R inputs > Behringer 305 stereo mixer)
Iteration 6: MTX9A > Doepfer A-121-3 > HPF > Mutable Inst. Clouds (Parasites alt. firmware / Oliverb mode) > Behringer 305 stereo mixer
Modulation: Buchla Quad Function Generator 281t, Behringer 150
Pitch and parametric equalization post-processing by Goldwave
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released September 16, 2022
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at the White Pillar Workshop, September 15th, 2022 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system, principally exploring the voice of Mutable Instruments Braids' wavetable algorithm. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photograph taken by L. Sheader (Thank you!) / Reprocessed by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ONE-22/258. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2022. All heights conserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Ascensoria
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Recorded 21st March 2025, initial testing session for Stairs, a stereo multimode analog ladder filter from After Later Audio.
PATCH NOTES:
Outputs 1 and 2 from Ornament & Crime (Quadraturia), novel waveform at 214.83 hertz, sent to L/R inputs of Stairs stereo ladder filter. Allen Synthesis EuroPi (Harmonic LFOs) sent five different curved sample & hold waveforms (1/7, 2/3, 3/6, 4/32, 5/17) to modulation inputs for Stairs' left and right frequency control, global frequency control, bias control (starve) and resonance control. A sixth waveform (6/23) was sent from EuroPi to Links 1:3 multiple, with two mults sent into MISO for inversion/attenuation, which were then routed into CV inputs 2 and 3 on Ornament, modulating the shape of the wavetable and the phase/frequency spread between outputs 1 and 2. Stairs' eight outputs - left and right outputs for high pass, band pass and both 12 and 24 decibel slope low pass - all sent to Doepfer A-138s and Toppobrillo Minimix stereo mixers for panning and mixing. Recorded live in GoldWave at 16 bit-depth and 48000 hertz sampling rate. Post-proc included selective time-domain pitch shifting.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Azimuth Years
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
I would write "Happy Summer Solstice" but it isn't a happy one this year. This year, it feels like some kind of downward, backward pull. And so, as we sink, this recording marks the Summer Solstice.
---
Sinking through the layers
Regressing to the outer borders
Approaching the darkened command centre
Edified in the blank landscape
You are here with the rest of us
Held in the thrall of another long winter
Telling ourselves it must be warm again someday
Until we just can't remember anything else
Maybe the world has always been this way?
I can only curl up beside a fire
Zoned and dethroned
And go to sleep until tomorrow

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Bin Tepe
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
This is the first iteration of 'Bin Tepe' - initially one of several outtakes/variations from the sixteen-oscillator session that produced 'Cenotaph' -  weltlandschaft.bandcamp.com/album/cenotaph  - presented here in two halves that together form the (w)hole.
'Bin Tepe' explores specific sections of the frequency spectrum, highlighting both lower and higher ends while diminishing much of the gulf between those areas, where most of the more "traditional" harmonic content in a droning chord exists. Instead, the listening experience is animated by a lively group of ear-tickling upper frequencies and supported by a foundation of almost totally subharmonic bass. Only here, in the world of sound and vibration, is it possible to stand at the top of a mountain peak and remain prostrate at its feet.

Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 5) 4. Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 6) 5. Buchla 258t / Oscillator 2 through Doepfer A-160-1 (Divider output /2) 6. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 1/2 of output 1) 11. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 3/2  and XOR of output 1) 12. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 2/1 and amplitude modulated +127 by output 3) 13. Ornament & Crime / Vector LFO (Sinewave, 65 Hz) 14. Ornament & Crime / Vector LFO (Inverse sinewave, 97 Hz) 15. Ornament & Crime / Ebb & LFO (Triangle wave, 166.6 Hz) 16. Ornament & Crime / Ebb & LFO (Subdivided triangle wave, 166.6 Hz) Voices 1-4 summed and filtered via Buchla 292t Quad Lo-Pass Gate, with outputs 1/2 panned hard L in Toppobrillo Minimix and outputs 3/4 panned hard R. Buchla 258t oscillator 2 frequency modulated by oscillator 1 (sinewave). Voices 5-8 each individually filtered via 2HP LPF, Beepboop Tape Sampler, Doepfer A-121-3 and Dave Smith Inst. DSM03, before being summed and panned via Doepfer A-138s - 5 and 6 panned hard L/R, 7 and 8 panned at 10 and 2. Voices 9-12 summed via Tiptop MISO, then sent in mono to Toppobrillo Minimix. Voices 13/14 summed via Doepfer A-135-2, then sent in mono to Toppobrillo Minimix. Voices 15/16 sent directly to Toppobrillo Minimix.  Following the above session, master bus used Pulsar W495. Original audio multed once through short staggered delay, then multed again through four different independently tuned ring modulators from MDA, Waldorf (D Pole) and Image Line (Effector, Frequency Shifter).  Final pass in GoldWave using overlaid dubs of the previous render state, processed independently through Frequency Blend, fast Fourier transforms, stereo delay and ring modulation.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Binding the Appointed
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Recorded October 2-27, 2024 using NonlinearCircuits' Fourier.
Clock source is A-188 (512) and A-188 (1024) routed into Boolean (CMOS Party), with NOR output sent into Doepfer A-160 clock divider, which sends the /4 output to clock input 1 on Fourier.
Fourier's two output paths are first sent to 2HP and Doepfer low-pass filters, then to Buchla 292 low pass gates (swept open and closed by Buchla Quad Function Generator 281), then to Strymon Magneto, to Starlab and finally to inputs 1 and 6 of the Toppobrillo Minimix, which are modulated in the panning from L/R by the Quad Function Generator 281 and Voltage Processor 257.
Post-proc in Goldwave with filters and FX from Arturia and Airwindows.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Chrysopoeian Waves
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
The first of a new open-ended serial catalog of work, consisting of music that has been entirely generated, shaped, processed and mastered within GoldWave - a digital audio software I've been using since I was in high school in the late 1990s.
GoldWave comes with a wide array of tools, including an Expression Evaluator, which uses mathematical expressions to generate various waveforms, sweeps and noise, and from this, GoldWave's extensive set of audio processors (such as standard utilities like ring modulation, pitch shifting, flange, delay, reverb, parametric equalization and high/low/bandpass filtering, but also including more esoteric processors like fast Fourier transforms and Frequency Blend) allow even simple sine or square waves to be built up into detailed and unique masses of sound.
In the very early days, I used to make music from scratch like this in GoldWave, but back then, I was learning as I went, and I did not know anything about synthesis like I do today. In this sense, 'Chrysopoeian Waves' is as much about me returning to bare basics for comfort's sake as it is about really going deeper into this familiar program to see what it can still teach me.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released January 1, 2025
W/P by Brian Grainger. Generated entirely within the GoldWave digital audio workstation at the White Pillar Workshop, 30th December 2024. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. This is Milieu Music number ☉M-25/1, Golden Mixture I. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

trackinfo.title: Chrysopoeian Waves II
trackinfo.lyrics: Take 2  Expression evaluator input for initial chord generation: 0.3*sin(2*pi*t*f)+0.3*sin(2*pi*t*f*1.2458)+0.7*sin(2*pi*t*f*1.4983) Dynamics (absolute value) > Invert right channel > Frequency Blend (-99% pitch shift mixed with original dry signal) > Fast Fourier transformed (FFT size: 15, overlap: 16x) with oscillator synthesis > Doppler pitch up > Reverse left channel > 10-stage stereo panned delay (0.1516 seconds) > Multed and ring modulated with a sinewave (275hz) > Stereo swapped and inverted ring modded sound > Mixed ring modulated sound into original sound at 00:00:00.830517 > Fast Fourier transformed (FFT size: 15, overlap: 16x) to shorten runtime to 25:20 > Doppler pitch down > 3-stage stereo panned delay (1.9835 seconds) > Multed audio, high-passed, added reverb, Frequency Blend down an octave with low pass filtering and feedback, 3-stage stereo panned delay (1.9835 seconds), seven-band equalizer removed all bands except 400 hertz, ring modulated via squarewave (430 hertz), low pass filtered, 10-stage stereo panned delay (0.1516 seconds), doppler pitch up an octave, Fast Fourier transformed (FFT size: 15, overlap: 16x) to lengthen runtime, mixed into original sound at 125% > Parametric and seven-band equalization applied > Doppler pitch down > Fast Fourier transformed (FFT size: 15, overlap: 16x) to lengthen runtime to 62:30 > 4-stage stereo panned delay (1.9835 seconds) > Fast Fourier transformed (FFT size: 15, overlap: 16x) to shorten runtime to 38:25

trackinfo.title: Chrysopoeian Waves IV
trackinfo.lyrics: 1. Speech synthesizer generates formant waveforms at 16 bit depth and 6000 hertz sample rate 2. Fast Fourier transform applied to elongate (Similarity) 3. Section of stable held tone isolated, looped, multiplied 4. Pitch-shifted up 5. Dynamic bandpass filter applied to isolate 425-435 hertz band 6. Amplified, truncated, pitch-shifted down 7. Absolute Value (Dynamics processor), invert right channel 8. Pitch-shifted down 9. Blare (Dynamics processor, oversaturation), volume 50% reduced 10. Pitch-shifted down, multed: Mult ring-modulated via 160 hertz sinewave 11. Multed variation mixed over original 12. Absolute Value (Dynamics processor), invert left channel 13. Pitch-shifted up, truncated 14. Fast Fourier transform applied to elongate (15/16) with oscillator synthesis 15. Truncated, right channel pitch-shifted down, truncated, left channel inverted 16. 10-stage fast stereo delay applied, stereo image corrected for level balance 17. Pitch-shifted down, truncated to final runtime 18. Stereo 2:1 soft compressor applied 19. Parametric equalization applied to roll off resonant high-end and 160 hertz range 20. Sample rate raised to Redbook standard for release
trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital
trackinfo.credits: from Chrysopoeian Waves IV, released April 12, 2025

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Circumambulation
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Circumambulation" is the fourth distinct session to have materialized from the unexpectedly tangential process that also brought "Cenotaph" and both iterations of "Bin Tepe" into the world.
The first session was recorded with sixteen different oscillators on 14th November 2024. The second session was recorded on 6th December 2024 using extensive post-processing in Airwindows, FL Studio and GoldWave.
The cover design is an experiment using displacement maps to cross-pollinate the LSZ logo from "Chrysopoeian Waves" alongside a Frantisek Kupka painting.
Happy Mother's Day to all of my mothers, and your mothers, and their mothers.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released May 11, 2025
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar Workshop in two sessions, 14th November and 6th December 2024. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ON-25/131. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

trackinfo.title: Circumambulation
trackinfo.lyrics: 1. Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 3) 2. Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 4) 3. Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 5) 4. Allen Synthesis EuroPi / Polysquare (Power chord, output 6) 5. Buchla 258t / Oscillator 2 through Doepfer A-160-1 (Divider output /2) 6. Buchla 258t / Oscillator 2 through Doepfer A-160-1 (Divider output /4) 7. Buchla 258t / Oscillator 2 through Doepfer A-160-1 (Divider output /8) 8. Buchla 258t / Oscillator 2 through Doepfer A-160-1 (Divider output /16) 9. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 65.10 Hz, output 1) 10. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 1/2 of output 1) 11. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 3/2  and XOR of output 1) 12. Ornament & Crime / Quadraturia (Near-squarewave, 2/1 and amplitude modulated +127 by output 3) 13. Ornament & Crime / Vector LFO (Sinewave, 65 Hz) 14. Ornament & Crime / Vector LFO (Inverse sinewave, 97 Hz) 15. Ornament & Crime / Ebb & LFO (Triangle wave, 166.6 Hz) 16. Ornament & Crime / Ebb & LFO (Subdivided triangle wave, 166.6 Hz) First pass (14th November 2024): Voices 1-4 summed and filtered via Buchla 292t Quad Lo-Pass Gate, with outputs 1/2 panned hard L in Toppobrillo Minimix and outputs 3/4 panned hard R. Buchla 258t oscillator 2 frequency modulated by oscillator 1 (sinewave). Voices 5-8 each individually filtered via 2HP LPF, Beepboop Tape Sampler, Doepfer A-121-3 and Dave Smith Inst. DSM03, before being summed and panned via Doepfer A-138s - 5 and 6 panned hard L/R, 7 and 8 panned at 10 and 2. Voices 9-12 summed via Tiptop MISO, then sent in mono to Toppobrillo Minimix. Voices 13/14 summed via Doepfer A-135-2, then sent in mono to Toppobrillo Minimix. Voices 15/16 sent directly to Toppobrillo Minimix.  Second pass (6th December 2024): Original source processed via Arturia Tape Mello Fi > Image Line high pass filter > Image Line parametric EQ > Arturia Mini Filter, then multed through a short staggered and inverted delay. Auxiliary send used Airwindows (Galactic, Srsly 2) and Image Line parametric. Master bus used Image Line Maximus. Post-proc included low pass filtering in Goldwave.
trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Col
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about: "Col" is the result of the first testing session with Nonlinearcircuits' This 2 Shall Pass - a two-input passive analogue XOR (exclusive or) gate that possesses some unique behaviors, with the design being taken from a 1970's electronics magazine. Here, it combines squarewaves from the Stylophone CPM DS-2 and two modules from Bastl (the Tea Kick and Noise Square), with a little bit of shaping assistance from the Buchla Quad Lo Pass Gate, using This 2 Shall Pass as a dual ring modulator alongside the oscillators' dry signals.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released June 17, 2025
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar Workshop, 18th April 2025 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D using a photograph of the Trift glacier in Summer 1971 taken by Matti & Keti. This is Milieu Music number ONE-25/108. Sound recording (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

trackinfo.title: Col
trackinfo.lyrics: NonlinearCircuits - This 2 Shall Pass:   Upper Input 1: Stylophone CPM DS-2 3340 oscillator 1 (Squarewave) Upper Input 2: Unpatched Upper Input 3: Stylophone CPM DS-2 3340 oscillator 2 (Squarewave) Output A: Xerest Pola input 1 Lower Input 1: Bastl Tea Kick (Squarewave) Lower Input 2: Unpatched Lower Input 3: Bastl Noise Square (Squarewave) Output B: SSDP switch mixer input 3 Stylophone and Bastl oscillators multed via Isobar Mimic to relay dry squarewave signals to Xerest Pola and SSDP switch mixer respectively, with the Bastl oscillators first going through a Takaab 3AT passive triple attenuator before going to the SSDP mixer. Summed output signals from Xerest Pola and SSDP sent into hard panned L/R inputs on Takaab Nearness, with Nearness being sent into Buchla 292t Quad Lo Pass Gate for slight softening, before being mixed in Toppobrillo Minimix.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Desacralization
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"We two are left:
as a blank wall, the world,
earth and the men who talk,
saying their space of life
is good and gracious,
with eyes blank
as that blank surface
their ignorance mistakes
for final shelter
and a resting-place."
-H.D., excerpt from 'We Two' (1924)
---
Seven variable waveform low-frequency oscillators held in suspension, six of them hard panned and shaped by 1005/1047 low-pass filters from Behringer's 2500 series, and the seventh in mono, shaped first by Noise Engineering's Kith Ruina gain, and subsequently filtered via Expert Sleepers' Disting Mk4 in the M5 low-pass filter mode.
Cat#: ON-24/050
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released February 20, 2024
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded live at White Pillar, February 19 2024 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Poem excerpt by H.D. Design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ON-24/050. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Desculptural
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
The first part of a diptych from Limestone Ziggurat, unifying several different concepts of duality and recursion through the use of seven different ring modulators processing thirteen different waveforms (generated from self-oscillating filters and phasers, feedbacking delays, audible-range LFOs and traditional oscillators).
1. Nonlinearcircuits Ming Rod ring modulator, receiving ramp and square waveforms from Buchla 258t.
2. Blue Lantern CMOS Party logic module, receiving audible-range pointed waveforms from Buchla 281t Quad Function Generator, with XOR output sent to After Later Audio Stairs. Expert Sleepers Disting Mk4 multi-tool module, in A2 (dual four-quadrant multiplier mode), receiving audible-range pointed waveforms from Buchla 281t, with the Disting's positive output signal sent to Stairs.
3. Befaco A*B+C dual four-quadrant multiplier, receiving sinewaves from Doepfer A-188-1 (256 stages) and Dave Smith Instruments DSM03 Feedback module in A1/B1, with Doepfer A-188-2 and Dreadbox Utopia's audible range LFO in A2/B2.
Utilities include Buchla 292t Quad Lo Pass Gate, After Later Audio Stairs stereo ladder filter, Mutable Instruments' Links (1:3 multiple) and Toppobrillo Minimix. Generated in Pittsburgh Modular Structure EP-420 and EP-270 cases, and recorded in GoldWave at 16-bit depth and 48000 hertz sampling rate. Post-proc completed in GoldWave using a nine-stage stereo panned delay and a parametric equalizer.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released April 30, 2025
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded in a post-anesthetic clarity at White Pillar, 29th April 2025 using the R-EW Audioholistics modular system. Mastered by The Analog Botanist in GoldWave. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D using visual sampling of "Landscape with Charon Crossing the Styx" by Joachim Patinir (1520-1524). This is Milieu Music number ON-25/119a. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Desecration of the Vainglorious Deific
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about: Originally recorded on March 11, 2024 using a Behringer Model D analog monosynth, loaned to me by close friend and visual guru Greg Lawhun to investigate a potentially misbehaving filter. Subsequent sessions with the Model D ended up producing the "Dis" triple-album, and shades of that album recur here, in a session focusing on running all of the oscillators back into each other to frequency modulate them and bend them into much different waveforms. The original recording was then overlaid onto itself two subsequent times, each iteration being re-tuned by ear to produce the triptych wall before you now.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released July 18, 2024
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, March 11 2024 (initial session) and July 15 2024 (final session) using Greg Lawhun's Behringer Model D analog monosynth. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Photography by Brian at White Pillar. This is Milieu Music number ONE-24/200. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Desiccated Triad
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
N.B. Timbral Ocean Ø
"Desiccated Triad" contains three different sessions from three different dates which all attempted to process recordings of atonal sound in tonal ways. None of the three pieces offered here turned out the way I'd originally theorized they would, given the lengthy list of on-paper processing steps and specific methods of synthesis I'd worked with, and perhaps because of this, I feel they are more unique and provocative. With experimental music such as this, it is sometimes preferable to say and write less about it, and simply let the sound speak, and so "Desiccated Triad" is offered to you without further commentary.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Dis
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
One of several drone sessions recorded using Behringer's reiteration of Moog's Minimoog / Model D analog monosynth. In this tripartite session, all three oscillators used different waveforms (see below) and were supplemented by the LFO brought into the audible range and mixed via the external input. Summed output slightly filtered via a Doepfer A-121-3 low pass filter before being routed through a Strymon Magneto four-head tape delay unit with outputs hard panned L/R through a Behringer 305 mixer.
Session 1 - Triangle wave oscillators, triangle LFO
Session 2 - All three square/pulse wave oscillators, square LFO
Session 3 - Ramp wave oscillators, square LFO
Special thanks to G.L. for graciously offering me his Model D during the time he is not using it. These sessions and this release are for him.

Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital

"And this is but an island in an ocean.
This is our home, third from the sun.
Let it be evergreen
Let it be evergreen
And this is but an island in an ocean.
This is our home, third from the sun.
God, keep it evergreen.
To keep it evergreen I would lay my life down."
-H. Kaylan, 1968

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Ecce Nihilo
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
A soft breath on the neck, invisible, pale
An echo of our past lives
Cold under the ambivalent sun
Always witnessing through a window, apart
Someone else's golden day, wondering what it must feel like
While they are held fast within a radiant whorl
Disintegrating, muted, helpless to look on
As I blankly survey the deep sky
Certain there was something in it I was trying to find
Source: Buchla 258t dual oscillator, Behringer 150 ring modulator
This is ONE-22/211

All heights unblurred.
This session is for W. Beckett - surely, a brilliant mind such as yours could not ever perish? Almost certainly, you are still there, swimming in the cosmos.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: F.P.R.
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
When started on December 25, 1946, F-1 became the first nuclear reactor in Europe to achieve a self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction. It was still in operation in the beginning of the 2010s, with a power level of 24 kW, making it, at that time, the world's oldest operating reactor.
77 years later, nuclear power has indeed advanced our civilization's technical capabilities, but in a dark irony, this progress came only with the unforgivably high cost of civility itself.
N.B. 2024: This recording was meant to be published on December 25, 2023, but due to the unexpected necessity of a deeper mastering pass, it has been held from publication until now. The intent behind this release is, unfortunately, still relevant.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Grass to Heel
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Upon the curvature of a hill
Grass to heel, ranges glimpsed
The glimmer of a sword like a noonday star
That guides the praying hands of a king"
The second tangential loop-based work built out of a feedback session with the Future Sound Systems MTX9A pin matrix, and another view of the endless. In contrast to the previous release, 'Upon the Curvature of a Hill', this album returns the looping structure to something seamless, resembling a wall, but ultimately just a cascading linearity of windows that do not have obvious recursive points. Every oscillation is a loop, every loop is an oscillation, suspending us in a liminal space that is not past or future, but forever the present moment.
Catalog designate: UR-23/061
Source sound: Future Sound Systems MTX9A pin matrix (feedback loops)
Image: Luigi Mayer / Reprocessed by ABM&D

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Halftone Burn
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Halftone Burn consists of two variations of the same recording, processed one after the other using a combination of fast Fourier transforms to alter the length of the recording in greater and smaller amounts, octaval pitch shifting and granular re-sampling, in order to achieve a sort of aural representation of the generational loss that occurs when you re-scan a photocopy over and over.
The original session was recorded on 25th December, 2023 with Vector LFO in Ornament & Crime driving four modules from Behringer's ARP 2500 remake line - the 1004 oscillator, the 1005 Modamp ring modulator and amplifier, the 1006 Filtamp low-pass filter and amplifier and the 1047 multimode filter and resonator. A wealth of such sessions exist in the archives, and will eventually see daylight when the time feels right.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Heaven is a Glass Forever Machine
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
All creative work is never truly finished. Formats, frames, all arbitrary lines placed carefully around the artist, as a construct designed to organize and commodify the materials generated by the creative mind. In their natural state, these materials are nothing more than evidence of a process in motion, which itself is within another cascading sea of processes. The absolute nature of creative thought is a state of endless and boundless exploration, done in the name of expression for its own sake, a joyous and all-encompassing communion with the forces of the universe, whatever they may be, and it exists outside of time, apart from everything.
This so-called act of finishing, of "turning in" a complete work, is nothing short of a job, an act of utterly mundane ritual and meaningless definition that still allows plenty of open space for the inscriptions of passersby, themselves allowed to scrawl into it whatever they wish to feel, passive and inert as they sometimes are. Forced contexts and retconned memories. Drawing this line of separation willfully around the creative act is what holds the pleasure of creation hostage - it provides an end to an otherwise continuous river of ideas and impulses, pure and reactive from one to the next, everything given time and space.
This is a river that has no beginning or end, it is simply in motion for as long as the artist draws breath, and it is as intricately a part of their ability to live and survive as all of the blood in their bodies. The creative act is everything. The work can never be finished. You lean down at the edge of the river and cup your hands to fill them with the water. As you do, you become aware of the reflections in the surface - every creative act, every idea, every accomplishment, every regret and consideration and revelation of human creativity is there, like a family tree, leading directly to you, to here, to now. All that follows is to simply become a part of it yourself.
In this way, the creative act provides an answer for that most basic of human needs - purpose, meaning, belonging. You can only ever be what you are. What may yet take you or I years of our lives to discover, the mouth of the river just laughs at us, and beckons us closer in our realization of what it has been all along.
That river carries with it all of the sediments from the river floor, from the water's edge, and the forests and mountains beyond it. Those mountains, an accumulation of this sediment, built only by time and entropy's forward march, which will in turn break them down again to rejoin the river as so much endless particulate. The statue inside the stone remains inside the stone - all the statues and monuments that have ever been built are waiting there, deep inside the rock, the totality of their constitution being nothing more than grains of sediment packed tightly together.
Excavating those monuments is only our feeble and human attempt to redefine the world as we'd like it to be, not quite realizing that irony creeps up, informing you that you haven't changed anything, you haven't made anything new, that such things are impossible given the grand scale of the natural world. Instead, all of your proposed alterations have been communion with that world, bringing yourself closer to the beautiful chaos that embodies the way of all things. Those reflections in the river's surface echo back to you - no different than a flesh and bone variation of the sediment of eroded mountains and sun-kissed beach sands, gathered up by the wind and the waters. So too are we here, in the creative act, looking in a cosmic mirror at ourselves, in all worlds and times.
This release is not a finished release, nor will it ever be. Even when the last piece of recorded sound is appended to it at some unnamed date in the future, it will be declared as incomplete. Any written record that testifies this release is complete will itself be a lie. It is the explicit intent of the artist that this album, and its darker half, both be considered as permanently incomplete.
N.B. - For more detailed information about each piece, usually including patch notes, explore the "Track info" sections of each individual recording. This release will be added to periodically and sporadically throughout the year, and the price of admission will remain the same. The cover design is likely to change as well, and prior generations of this design will be included with this release as bonus downloadable files.

trackinfo.title: 2022.01.06 01:07 AM
trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital
trackinfo.about: Four Karplus Strong synthesizer voices (Mutable Inst. Braids + Rings, 2HP Pluck) sequenced by Quantermain in Ornament & Crime, playing "Porcupine" scales with CV source via Euclidean pattern generation. These signals are combined with a Doepfer A-135-2 mixer, reduced to mono, then multed (Behringer 173) and routed into two lowpass filters (Doepfer A-121-3 + 2HP, modulated by two different EGs with differing rates), and sent onward to Strymon Magneto in stereo, whose wet sound is multed and sent to Mutable Inst. Clouds. Magneto also uses a Disting Mk4's mono to stereo reverb (L3) for an auxiliary send, and many aspects of Magneto and Clouds are modulated/triggered via several different LFOs and trigger outputs from Blue Lantern's CMOS Party (Boolean gates) and CuteLab's Missed Opportunities (probabilistic gates). The final result of these two modules' outputs is sent into a Behringer 305 stereo mixer and recorded.
trackinfo.credits: from Heaven is a Glass Forever Machine, released January 5, 2022

trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital

trackinfo.title: 2022.01.11 04:32 PM
trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital
trackinfo.about: A quick recording of a patch that came and went, experimenting with 2HP's Pluck module playing a Phrygian scale with Euclidian sequencing, modulated by different LFOs before being sent into Clouds for probabilistic granular processing. In short, I finally need more VCAs.
trackinfo.credits: from Heaven is a Glass Forever Machine, released January 5, 2022

trackinfo.title: 2022.02.28 06:25 PM
trackinfo.label: Milieu Music Digital
trackinfo.about:
Third session to date with Tiptop's model 258t and 281t Buchla modules. Ornament and Crime is being sent three different triggers from Missed Opportunities - each one probabilistically subtractive based on the previous one - which is itself receiving master clock signal from CMOS Party, which is generating Boolean gates from two clock divider outputs coming from a Doepfer A-160-1 (global clock from Behringer 150).
With these three triggers, Ornament uses Euclidean sequencing as CV source to play three different generative melodic passages in mixolydian scales. The first two sequences are conveyed through the two oscillator voices of the Buchla 258t, while the third is sent to the v/oct input of Clouds.
Both of the 258t's VCOs are sent into low-pass filters (2HP + Doepfer A-121-3) that are themselves separately modulated/swept by an array of four different LFOs (from Dreadbox Ataxia/Utopia/Behringer 150>Wildfire Labs Equation Group) that are mixed via a Doepfer A-135-2 VC mixer, and modulated inversely (the VCA path of LFOs 1-4 are modulated by LFOs 4/2/3/1) and these outputs are sent to Tiptop MISO for mixing and multing.
The 2xVCO signals are multed from their respective LPF outputs and sent to Clouds and Strymon Magneto, which are both summed via Disting Mk4's E5 stereo compressor, and sent to Behringer 305's first two hard-panned inputs.
The Buchla 281t has brought all four envelopes into the audible range, and tuned by ear into a four-part chordal structure, grouped into 2 envelopes each and sent into the 305's third and fourth panned inputs to provide a nearly static drone bed beneath the wavering melodic passages generated by the 258t.
Somewhere in the process of the recording, pitches began to deviate slightly - possibly from voltage bleeding through some of the LFOs - although the effect is still pleasant enough to listen to that I found this admissible.
trackinfo.credits: from Heaven is a Glass Forever Machine, released January 5, 2022

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Impulse
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
'Impulse' is a session exploring the range of a digital synthesizer that is designed to emulate the SID chip within the Commodore 64. Whether or not this emulation comes close to the original chip is not necessarily the point of the investigation, but rather, what possibilities are brought forward when these sounds and designs have been migrated into a DAW environment. The resultant session is a humming turbine engine, not heard necessarily, but felt through several resonant spaces inside of a metallic structure.
Cat#: ONE-23/046
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released February 16, 2023
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar, February 14-15, 2023. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by ABM&D. Cover image courtesy of NASA / Gently halftoned by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ONE-23/046. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2023. All blights deserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Initiation Wells
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Hurricane Helene has devastated Asheville, North Carolina. It is a mountain hippie city where I got married in 2004, where I saw Autechre play in 2015, where I considered spending my twilight years in the time before I decided to leave the Carolinas forever. Despite being in the mountains, the whole place is underwater.
"Initiation Wells" is a set of multiple takes (my first) exploring the Nonlinearcircuits Triple Sloths module, which outputs a set of three very slow modulation sources that are derived from Lorenz attractors, and here illustrates those movements through the three axes of Synthesis Technology's E352 Cloud Terrarium wavetable synthesizer. It has nothing at all to do with Asheville, or hurricanes, or human suffering - which is why I am using it to raise money for the rescue and restoration efforts underway in Asheville at this moment, doing my very best from hundreds of miles away in Ohio to help out this city that I love dearly as much as I can.
All money made from "Initiation Wells" will be sent to BeLoved Asheville -  belovedasheville.com  - a very awesome group dedicated to all kinds of relief and assistance. Any purchase of $25 or more will receive a download code for a divine bonus recording that isn't publicly available otherwise. The code is not automatic, but will be emailed to you manually by yours truly once the purchase comes through on my end.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Interference Patterns
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
A testing session with the Isobar Mimic, a quad-buffered multiple, which now along with Mutable Instruments' Links (see: Alsciaukat  weltlandschaft.bandcamp.com/album/alsciaukat  ) has retired and replaced my Behringer 173.
---
Mimic input 1: Cre8audio Chips VCO 1
1. Out to 305 mixer, panned 10
2. Out to Chips VCO 2 pulsewidth input
Mimic input 2: Cre8audio Chips VCO 2
1. Out to 305 mixer, panned 2
2. Out to Chips VCO 1 filter input
Mimic input 3: Doepfer A-188-2 Output A
1. Out to 305 mixer, panned R
2. Out to Behringer Filtamp > A-188-2 external feedback input
Mimic input 4: Doepfer A-188-2 Output B
1. Out to 305 mixer, panned L
2. Out to Behringer Modamp > A-188-2 audio input
305 output sent L/R into inputs 1/2 of Buchla 292t Quad Lo Pass Gate, slightly filtered, then sent to Toppobrillo Minimix inputs 1/6 panned L/R. Recorded live in GoldWave at 16-bit depth and 48000 hertz sampling rate. Post-proc in FL Studio included Airwindows (Distance, Weight) and Waldorf 's D-Pole filter.

released January 18, 2025

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Interior Landscaping
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Interior Landscaping" is a record I've imagined for many years, having a long-time fascination with the overtones and combined frequencies in various rooms and buildings I've lived in.
What I mean to say by this, probably ungracefully, is that every now and again, there is a beautiful culmination of harmonic information floating in the air, an entirely incidental mixture of appliance and electrical humming, partially blocked duct work and vents, and perhaps even something in the close vicinity outside the building, such as a nearby lawnmower or road work crew.
During moments like these, I've tried very hard to locate the most ideal physical position in a given room to record it, which is quite difficult, when the specific combination of sounds can only be "glimpsed" while standing in one exact spot, with my ear turned to one exact direction.
The recordings offered here are probably the very closest I have ever been able to get to capturing a moment like this. Even now, as I type this, fully content with the quality of the audio-fabric I'm offering to you, I can unequivocally state that I only managed to capture a facet of the real room tone I was trying to record. These pieces have turned out well, despite this, so I come away relatively satisfied with the attempt, but I am sure I will continue to try again and again later, and when that happens, it will be interesting to have this release in hand to compare it with.
Musically, texturally, and so on, "Interior Landscaping" takes cues from many of my favorite atmospheric artists, from Aube, Howard Stelzer, Rod Modell, Francisco Lopez, Richard Chartier and Nicholas Maloney - the latter of whom was particularly influential to me on this release through his superb box set "Forms Within Spaces," which I had the pleasure of publishing for him at Psoma Psi Phi in 2020, five years ago almost to the day.
And five is most certainly the magic number here - Nicholas' album and my own are both five pieces that run for exactly one hour - and again and again many times over it is possible to find synchronicity of the numerical, thematic, musical and otherwise when dealing in abstracts and minimalism.
This is perhaps one of many reasons why laboring for hours over music that presents itself as disarmingly simplistic is so rewarding, like applying dozens of coats of paint to a canvas that are each so thin that the naked eye cannot detect them, but without those layers, the piece is not the piece.
And in this situation, when I am working with nothing more than the sound of air and hum in an empty room, shaping it and layering it into something that resembles a chordal structure, I am once again confounded by the possible density of something that is not really there.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released June 27, 2025

Secondary shaping and equalization work completed on 26th February 2025. Final assembly work with GoldWave and two hard-panned ring modulators completed 26th-27th June 2025. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number AT-25/178. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Isotelus
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
While searching old hard drives and backups for something else, as it often happens, I happened upon this session of primordial Ziggurat from Autumn of 2020, apparently recorded impulsively, perhaps meant for some other project or purpose, but either way labeled as "Ziggurat" and filed away to be forgotten about.
Much like the three pieces plucked from the early archives on "Adamantinarx" and the three "Litho" takes, "Isotelus" offers yet another glimpse of what was gestating in those first two years of my modular development with regard to Limestone Ziggurat - a project I had already conceptualized and named by mid-2020, but wanted to hold back from announcing and publishing for a while, so I could consider it more carefully. I knew then that Limestone Ziggurat, whatever it would become, was going to be my "next phase" of creative working and thinking, and so as the fifth year of my travels with my modular system now begins, I felt it pertinent to share this look back.
So what has changed? What has remained the same? It's clear that this session was probably done stoned, hence my forgetting about it, and also because it resembles a fair bit of the first and third "OHMM" releases, which were themselves recorded that same month. At this early stage, influences from O))) and other sub-bass explorers are obvious, and in a strange modular music way, "Isotelus" almost feels like Ziggurat doing a doom album.
Altogether, it still thrills me to listen to it now with a nice pair of headphones, excessively loud, almost five years later, and it makes me even more excited to think about how much more distance and time Ziggurat still has yet to cross. Maximum volume, as ever, will yield maximum results.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: LC9x9
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
LC9x9 is one of several stress tests recorded within the Doepfer LC9 modular case, one third of the greater R-EW Audioholistics modular system, which utilizes several less-stable sound sources that tend to deviate in pitch more easily over longer runtimes.
Primarily, the voices of both oscillators in Cre8audio's Chipz module are heard, alongside Wildfire Laboratories' Sovereign oscillator, with supplemental assistance from two Doepfer A-188 BBD units (256 and 1024 stages), a Doepfer Phase Locked Loop module, filtering via Beepboop's Tape Sampler and gain coloration via Wildfire Labs' Weird Vector (high and low rectifiers) and Sandevistan, Beepboop's Kontact gain/piezo and Noise Engineering's Kith Ruina overdrive.
Everything was summed via Dreadbox's Utopia, Wildfire Labs' Equation Group and SSDP's switch mixer before being final glossed with parametric EQ, compression and additional filtering on the computer.
Cat#: ON-24/092
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released April 5, 2024
W/P by Brian Grainger. Recorded at White Pillar using 1/3 of the R-EW Audioholistics modular system in a Doepfer LC9 case, April 1st 2024. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text and design by ABM&D. This is Milieu Music number ON-24/092. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2024. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Like a Noonday Star That Guides the Praying Hands of a King
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
"Upon the curvature of a hill
Grass to heel, ranges glimpsed
The glimmer of a sword like a noonday star
That guides the praying hands of a king"
'Like a Noonday Star That Guides the Praying Hands of a King' concludes the unanticipated polyptych of five loop studies, each meditating on an aspect of a poem that has been reproduced with each release.
These recordings have organically surfaced while working on other sessions, sections of modular improvisation, generative music and feedback that caught my ear in a certain noteworthy way, and were set aside to fulfill entirely different purposes.
In many ways, this is the core philosophical view that informs all five releases, the notion that entire worlds of sound always exist in the periphery of what may otherwise seem like a very focused creative vision, which both humbles and frustrates me, leaving me feeling as if I do not quite grasp the profundity of the sound being brought into existence by my own tools, and often makes me wonder how much has been lost in the act of throwing away so-called 'failed' work?
These five releases do not provide any real answer, beyond their self-evident nature, illustrating that the craftsman does not necessarily know what is best for his craft, that this is a realization of the human condition, at the mercy of estimation and imprecise prediction. Arthur Machen once prosaically described the creative act in this way: "One dreams in fire and works in clay."
So what remains here is one last recurrent structure - an isolated fragment of a larger session with a Karplus-Strong digital synthesizer and a digital reiteration of a four-head tape delay machine, which was initially recorded on June 18th, 2021, and subsequently also yielded three other expansive loop-based pieces for Milieu's 'River Ores IX' in the Vibratelepathos series. This piece is a more drone-oriented shadow of those three loop studies, which are more melodically informed, and I find myself beautifully lost within its drifting tone, waiting for and pleasantly re-experiencing the one broken moment in the wavering line, where the loop shifts and restarts, making the mathematical simplicity of the work's design apparent.
In the end, so much preparatory effort and sonic experimentation is broken down into the most earnest of parts, each one like a small gem through which we can see a small portion of the past, repeated ad infinitum - or ad nauseam, depending on your level of patience and expectation - and I am where I was always meant to be, again standing here where I started, considering the creative act, pondering my placement within it, left with more questions than answers as the loop drones on, ambivalent.
Catalog designate: UR-23/176a
Source sound: 2HP Pluck Karplus-Strong paraphonic digital synthesizer
Image: Luigi Mayer / Reprocessed by ABM&D
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:
released June 25, 2023

Recorded principally during a session at White Pillar on June 18th, 2021 using 2HP's Pluck synthesizer and Strymon's Magneto delay unit, and developed into its final loop study on May 8th, 2023. Mastered by The Analog Botanist. Text by Brian. Design by ABM&D using visual sampling of 'Cathedral at Tortosa' by Luigi Mayer, c. 1800. (C) + (P) Oscillog 2023. All nights preserved.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Long Days, Pleasant Nights
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Screens shuddered to life in the abandoned complex
Their readouts dimmed by the layer of dust that blanketed all of the strange equipment from the old world
Humming with long lines of warming voltage
Generated by one of the massive beams far above the facility
I wiped one of the monitors to read the cascade of dots and text
NORTH CENTRAL POSITRONICS
TETHERING STATION 1193815717
NEW PARAMETER? Y/N
As my finger hovered over the worn keys, I wondered how long it had been
Still blinking, the cursor refused to offer an answer
And I had the sinking feeling that these machines were unaware that the world had already moved on
Entering the inputs I'd scraped from the mono keypad in Lud, I hoped the machines would comply
LOAD PROGRAM?
PRESS RETURN TO PROCEED OR ESC TO QUIT
Soon after hitting the key, a loading bar illuminated on a smaller adjacent machine
Yellow and steadily climbing through percentages, stopping only briefly at 19% before continuing on
As the process completed, the entire building shook, knocking down a shelf of green glass alembics in the corner behind me
Droning from far beneath the ground, the sound of turbines spinning to life
Grinding through what must have been an epoch of rust
Now returned to their metallic oscillation
O DISCORDIA appeared on the screen in a glaring red
LINKS TO << FEDIC / NYC / EMPATHICA / NFK / HAMBRY / TOPEKA >> RE-ESTABLISHED // ALL OTHERS OFFLINE

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Low Bedrooms
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about: Two early sessions experimenting with the Nonlinearcircuits Fourier and the Moog Subharmonicon in conversation, originally recorded on different evenings in October 2024. Both sessions involved additional post-processing passes with various sound tools from GoldWave, Airwindows, Image Line and Arturia. The second session was also supplemented by an ARP Odyssey synthesizer. Fourier, Subharmonicon and Odyssey are all radically different machines, but work together in a unique type of synergy. More detailed patch notes for both sessions are included in the sub-menus of each track.
Limestone Ziggurat.credits:

Photograph taken by Brian at White Pillar, 1st November 2016. This is Milieu Music number ON-24/281. (C) + (P) Oscillog ASCAP 2025. All nights preserved.

trackinfo.title: ON-24/281a
trackinfo.lyrics: Monday, October 7, 2024 8:27 PM Moog set to 8-Just Intonation, with direct outputs of VCO 1's subharmonic outputs both clocking Fourier's Sine and Cosine inputs. VCO1+2 pulsewidth modulation sourced from 2x Inertia outputs from NonlinearCircuits Triple Sloths (Lorentz attractors). Full summed mix of the Subharmonicon, including both oscillators and all four sub-oscillators sent into 2HP LPF low-pass filter. Fourier's individual outputs both sent into Buchla 292t Quad Lo-Pass Gate, then into Doepfer A-121-3 low-pass filter. Filtered mixes of both Fourier and Moog summed in a Doepfer A-138s, and then processed through Strymon Magneto's four-head delay system, with hard-panned L/R outputs mixed in the Toppobrillo Minimix. Recorded live in GoldWave direct from Toppobrillo, with post-processing work (additional filter shaping, parametric equalization and compression) being completed in GoldWave and FL Studio 21. Secondary post-proc pass in FL21 using Frequency Shifter, ring modulator, Arturia Mello Fi and Airwindows (Chamber, To Tape 6).

trackinfo.lyrics: Patch notes (2025.03.19):  Voix: Ornament & Crime (Quadraturia, 111.95 Hz novel waveform) Filters: 2HP LPF, BeepBoop Tape Samp, DSM03, Disting Mk4, Doepfer A-121 EG: NLC Triple Sloths, Buchla Quad Func Gen Time: N/A Sequencing: N/A  Modulation: NLC Triple Sloths FX: Magneto, Starlab, 2x Clouds, Multi Versio Utilities: Links Mixing: Doepfer A-135/138s, MISO, Buchla Quad Lo Pass, Toppobrillo Mini  Four novel waveform voices in Quadraturia sourced from a 111.95 hertz wavetable oscillator, mixed via Doepfer A-135 VC mixer with three VCA modulation sweeps from Triple Sloths and one from Buchla Quad Function Generator. Mult 2 sent to Mutable Instruments' Clouds (A), then to Buchla Quad Lo Pass Gate in combo mode, then Toppobrillo Minimix. Mult 3 sent to Mutable Instruments' Clouds (B), then to Noise Engineering's Multi Versio in reverb mode, then to Toppobrillo Minimix. Full mix recorded and broadcast live in OBS.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Molybdos
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
'Molybdos' is a held-tone composition that explores two low-frequency squarewave oscillators (generated by the Vector LFO mode in Ornament & Crime's Hemispheres alternative firmware, each with a slightly different pulsewidth) beating against each other at 57.02 Hz and 58.01 Hz respectively. Both oscillators were then summed and shaped through a Behringer 1005 Modamp ring modulator and 1006 Filtamp low-pass filter, before being multed with signal 1 sent directly into a Noise Engineering Xerest Pola stereo mixer, and signal 2 being processed through an SSDP Jade series phaser, with the all-pass filter output sent into Xerest Pola alongside signal 1. The phaser employed a Behringer 1004 oscillator in low-range mode for subtle frequency modulation, and the resultant recording was further post-processed in three different ways - via a three-part panned delay in Goldwave, a FFT/granular resampler in Goldwave and a third pass combining both.
Desolate, commanding sound that forms a wall around the listener, with hypnotic modulation and a timbral profile that recalls power stations or large electrical generators, 'Molybdos' exists alongside sessions undertaken for the 'OHMM' series and other heavier works such as 'Pillar of Persephone.' Inspired in large part by the ring modulation studies conducted by David Burraston at Noyzelab, and offered here with thanks to Burraston for his generous sharing of knowledge.

Limestone Ziggurat.title: Moment of Landscape
Limestone Ziggurat.label: Milieu Music Digital
Limestone Ziggurat.about:
Even the most bitter cold must yet give way
Pushed back into the clouds
As the ground begins to warm
Cloaked in green
Sun cast and half-dreaming
Dressed in shoots and blooms
Nascent and upward flung birth
Another life, unaware of the last
Listening for a name to be spoken
From the slumbering lips of Persephone
Onward, outward, upward still
Toward and transcendent
Never outrunning and always becoming
Ever branching and ever the same
Music of the sphere
Our island held in the abandoned abyss
Modulated by the inverse of that old darkness
---
Issued in celebration of the Spring Equinox, 20th March 2025.
Recorded on 13th January 2025, using four layered iterations of two ring-modulated sinewaves processed through the Doepfer A-189-1 VBM in the following configurations: Multiplication, Multiplication (Inverse), Addition and Delay Mode 4. The ninth session, shaped by non-Ixian machines from Wildfire Laboratories - "adversarial electronics" - incl. Sovereign (voltage-starved diode oscillator), Lucy Says No (feedback loop), Yanqui (non-controllable fixed frequency oscillator), Sandevistan (dual diode rectifiers/gains/piezo plates), Weird Vector (passive utilities) and Equation Group (passive resistor ladder). Post-proc included Strymon's Magneto four-head tape delay system, Airwindows (Distance, Galactic), Arturia's Mello Fi and Image Line's Frequency Shifter, with Audio Damage's Rough Rider 3 on the master buss.
Sometimes, heavy shit can happen in the ninth. Listen with headstones, as Count Yorga would be fond of saying.
